Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Developmental Evolution of Limb Morphology
Award.AbstractNarration: Animal species display tremendous diversity in body size and shape, yet relatively little is known regarding the genetic mechanisms responsible for these differences. The objective of this project is to examine this question by determining whether species that exhibit similar limb lengths acquire these comparable limb morphologies through related developmental mechanisms. Anolis lizards are ideal for these studies since they display remarkable differences in limb length between species. During the course of this project the pattern of limb growth and gene expression will be compared between multiple different long-limbed and short-limbed Anolis species. In addition, Anolis species with naturally occurring differences in DNA sequences that control hindlimb formation will be investigated to determine whether these sequence differences can directly alter the function of limb genes. These developmental and molecular analyses will reveal whether different species with similar body forms achieve a similar final appearance through the same or different means. The proposed studies will also generate broader impacts through the creation of new teaching and training opportunities for undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral scholars, as well by providing resources that will advance Anolis lizards as a new model system for developmental studies. Finally, the project will integrate research and education through a research module that has been developed for an advanced undergraduate molecular genetics laboratory course.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Animal species display tremendous diversity in body size and shape, yet relatively little is known regarding which genes are responsible for these differences. The objective of this project was to examine this question by determining whether species that evolved similar limb sizes acquired their similar limb morphologies through the same genetic and developmental mechanisms. Anolis lizards were ideal for these studies since they display remarkable differences in limb length between species. We discovered separate DNA sequence deletions in an ancient hindlimb regulatory element have occurred in multiple short-limbed species of anole lizard. This hindlimb element controls expression of the tbx4gene, which is important for leg development. Using mice, we tested the function of hindlimb elements from a long-limbed lizard species and short-limbed lizard species, and we found that the short-limbed hindlimb element has reduced function. Our data are consistent with the hypothesis that the hindlimb element sequence deletions cause reduced levels of tbx4 gene expression, which subsequently result in smaller legs. Thus, the project has yielded important new insights into how changes in limb size evolve. During this project we also produced new genome resources for Anolis lizards, including a genome assembly the brown anole (produced with collaborators) and multiple gene expression and chromatin data sets. In addition, we developed new methods to anesthetize lizards and to surgically access oocytes to aid in the establishment gene editing approaches in these reptiles. Further impacts from the project include advancing the scientific training of 1 postdoctoral fellow, 5 graduate students and 12 undergraduate students.
